fields.name: THOMAS M. CUSHING
fields.bio: Thomas Cushing was appointed to fill a Cook County Circuit Court vacancy in June 2019 and currently hears cases in the domestic violence court. Cushing was previously an attorney in private practice, working on civil and commercial litigation, personal injury, and appellate cases. Cushing has also worked in environmental law. Cushing ran unsuccessfully for judge in 2014 and 2016.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA and ISBA noted Cushing’s “extensive” litigation experience and his demeanor. The CCL praised him for his litigation skills and wrote that he “has been involved with numerous community activities, including teaching and environmental advocacy.”

fields.name: MARGARET STANTON McBRIDE
fields.bio: Margaret McBride has been a judge for more than 30 years. McBride was elected by Cook County circuit judges as an associate judge in 1987, and three years later was elected to the circuit court. McBride was retained in 2006 and then, two years later, was first elected to the appellate court. Since 2016 she has also served as an appellate court representative on the 16-member Illinois Courts Commission, the body that imposes discipline for judicial misconduct. Before becoming a judge, McBride was an assistant state’s attorney for ten years.
fields.notable: As a Circuit Court judge, McBride was appointed the first-ever domestic violence coordinator for the Circuit Court, helping to make domestic courts more child-friendly.
fields.ratingNotes: McBride was praised for her integrity and legal knowledge. The CBA said she has a “distinguished track record” as an Appellate Court justice. The ISBA said she is “very principled and committed to justice” and is “efficient and polite, but direct.” CCL said, “She has an excellent reputation for leading initiatives that lead to meaningful reforms.”

fields.name: ANTHONY LUCAFO
fields.bio: Anthony Lucafo has been an assistant state’s attorney since 2006, and he currently prosecutes domestic violence and sexual assault cases. Before he became a lawyer, Lucafo was executive director of the Near Northwest Civic Committee, a non-profit that provided after school and summer programming for youth. Lucafo is also an adjunct professor of law at Chicago-Kent College of Law.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA noted that Lucafo is “well-versed in the law” and has experience in “complex matters.” The CBA cited his “extensive trial experience” and his legal knowledge, and the CCL highlighted his willingness to mentor young prosecutors.

fields.name: FRANK R. DiFRANCO
fields.bio: After beginning his career as an assistant state’s attorney, Frank DiFranco has worked in private practice since 1994. He represents clients in civil and criminal cases, including wrongful death and personal injury cases.
fields.notable:
DiFranco is accused in a pending civil lawsuit of helping disgraced former detective Reynaldo Guevara frame a man named Jose Maysonet for a double murder in July 1990. According to the suit, DiFranco, who had just begun working in felony review for the state’s attorney’s office, took a coerced confession from Maysonet and his girlfriend after a marathon interrogation session in which Guevara repeatedly beat him. The suit also alleges that DiFranco lied on the stand during Maysonet’s trial when he said that he took the confession in English, even though Maysonet did not speak fluent English at the time, according to his attorney. In a deposition taken last year, DiFranco maintained that he took Maysonet’s statement in English. Maysonet’s conviction was vacated in 2016 and in 2017 prosecutors decided not to re-try the case.

In an email to *Injustice Watch*, DiFranco denied Maysonet’s allegations and said that he still believes that Maysonet is guilty. “I have never and would never fabricate a statement of a defendant or anyone else for that matter,” he wrote.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted DiFranco’s “extensive experience in a wide range of civil and criminal matters.” The ISBA said there were some “mixed comments” on his temperament, with a few attorneys saying he could be “argumentative at times.” The CCL said he “enjoys a reputation of being a zealous and knowledgeable advocate.”

fields.name: DANIEL EDWARD MALONEY
fields.bio: Judge Daniel E. Maloney presides over municipal cases at the Markham Courthouse. Maloney, appointed in 2019 to a 3rd subcircuit Cook County Circuit Court vacancy, spent the first 16 years of his career working as an assistant Cook County state’s attorney, where he prosecuted drug cases before joining the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration as division counsel in 2017.
fields.notable: In 2009, as a Cook County prosecutor, Maloney worked with DEA agents and the State’s Attorney’s office on an investigation into two drug rings importing from Mexico that resulted in 10 arrests and the seizure of more than $8.7 million worth of heroin and cocaine. The drug bust was one of the largest in county history.
fields.ratingNotes: CBA noted Maloney’s legal knowledge and demeanor. ISBA said opposing attorneys described him as “a tough litigator, but fair and ethical.” CCL said, “He is reported to be an excellent mentor to less experienced lawyers.”

fields.name: LAUREN BROUGHAM GLENNON
fields.bio: Lauren Brougham Glennon has worked in private practice since 2006, in law firms and then, since 2017, in solo practice. Her practice has covered a number of legal areas, including property tax law. She began her career as an assistant corporation counsel in the Chicago Law Department. She previously ran in and lost the 2014 race for the 3rd subcircuit.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL praised Glennon’s experience in “a variety of legal areas.” However, the CBA wrote that “at this stage of her career she does not possess the requisite depth and breadth of legal experience to effectively serve as a Circuit Court Judge.” The ISBA also raised concerns about her lack of jury trial and courtroom litigation experience.

fields.name: JOY E. TOLBERT NELSON
fields.bio: Nelson has worked as an assistant Cook County state’s attorney since 1999. She is currently assigned  as lead attorney in the felony trial division in the Maywood Courthouse.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA rated her not recommended despite her “excellent temperament,” citing concerns about her “legal knowledge and legal ability” stemming from her lack of civil practice experience. The CCL praised her litigation experience and temperament. The ISBA said attorneys reported she is “diligent and trustworthy.”

fields.name: Illinois Supreme Court candidate Harris accused of ethical breach involving nephew’s case
BRADLEY R. TROWBRIDGE
fields.bio: Bradley R. Trowbridge specializes in divorce and family law. He opened his own firm, the Law Offices of Bradley R. Trowbridge, in 2012. He has been licensed to practice law since 2000, and has also worked in legal aid and served as an assistant corporation counsel for the City of Chicago. Before he became a lawyer, Trowbridge was a social worker for 10 years. He has offered legal services to victims of domestic violence and has emphasized working along with the LGBTQ community.
fields.notable: Trowbridge has unsuccessfully run for the Cook County Circuit Court in 2012 and 2018.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA emphasized Trowbridge’s litigation and arbitration experience and wrote that he is considered “professional, civil and fair.” The CCL highlighted his legal ability and litigation skills but noted that “a few respondents questioned his temperament.”

fields.name: OWENS "JOE" SHELBY
fields.bio: Owens “Joe” Shelby has been an assistant state’s attorney in Cook County for the past 11 years. He previously served as assistant counsel to the Office of the Speaker in the Illinois House of Representatives. Shelby says his service to his community is exemplified by his membership on the boards of multiple westside organizations, including the National Black Prosecutors’ Association, the NAACP Westside Chapter, and the Better Boys Foundation.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA wrote, “Mr. Shelby has handled several felony and misdemeanor trials and has had some juvenile and civil experience.” The ISBA and CCL praised his legal ability and temperament, but noted some concerns about his limited experience in complex litigation.

fields.name: CYNTHIA Y. COBBS
fields.currentJob: Serving as Appellate Court judge by assignment
fields.bio:
Cynthia Cobbs has been serving as an Illinois Appellate Court judge by assignment of the Illinois Supreme Court since 2015. Cobbs is seeking the Supreme Court seat long held by her mentor, retired justice Charles Freeman.

Cobbs was a social worker in Maryland before moving to Illinois, attending law school and being admitted to the Illinois bar in 1988. Cobbs went to work as a law clerk for Freeman, a position she held for years; she then worked as an attorney for the state courts until, in 2002, she was named director of the state courts.

In 2011, the Illinois Supreme Court appointed Cobbs to a vacancy on the Cook County Circuit Court, a position that legal experts questioned because Cobbs was then living in Will County. She moved to Cook County, and won election to the circuit court seat in 2014. The following year Cobbs was assigned to the appellate court.
fields.notable: Cobbs, Howse and Neville all are seeking to become, after Freeman, the second black elected Supreme Court justice in Illinois history.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA praised Cobbs’s legal knowledge and demeanor and said she has “extensive knowledge about the administration and operation of the court system.” The ISBA said, “She is considered to be fair-minded, patient and intelligent.” The CCL said she is always prepared and has “established herself as both a solid trial court jurist and as an appellate court judge.”

fields.name: SUSANNE MICHELE GROEBNER
fields.currentJob: Assistant state’s attorney in McHenry County
fields.bio: Susanne Groebner currently works as an assistant state’s attorney in McHenry County after spending 17 years as a prosecutor in Cook County, where she was last assigned to a felony courtroom in Rolling Meadows. Groebner also has experience in civil litigation, particularly in the area of family law.
fields.notable: Groebner previously ran for judge as a Republican. She lost the 2018 Republican primary for a 13th subcircuit seat to Gary Seyring.
fields.ratingNotes: The bar associations noted Groebner’s experience trying complex cases. The CBA said she is “well respected by judges and lawyers for her knowledge of the law, outstanding trial skills, fine demeanor and temperament.” The CCL praised her as “an honest and fair prosecutor.” ISBA said she is “well prepared, honest, and impartial.”

fields.name: TYRIA B. WALTON
fields.bio: Tyria Walton was appointed to the bench in May 2019, and currently oversees traffic cases at the Daley Center. Previously, she served for more than two decades as an assistant public defender, where she worked in the felony trial division defending first-degree murder cases.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted that Walton “served on the Public Defender’s Murder Task Force” and that she “serves as a mentor for children and young adults in the Englewood community.” The CCL praised her legal ability and “substantial litigation experience in complex matters.” The ISBA highlighted her community involvement and her “high integrity.”

fields.name: PATRICIA M. FALLON
fields.bio: Patricia M. Fallon was appointed to fill the Hanlon vacancy in May 2019. She currently oversees First Municipal District traffic cases in the Daley Center. Before her appointment to the bench, Fallon was the chief of human resources in the Cook County Recorder of Deeds office. Before that, Fallon worked in the labor and employment litigation unit of the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office for more than 12 years, including almost two years as a supervisor. In that role, she defended the county against employment discrimination lawsuits.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA cited Fallon’s knowledge, trial experience and “excellent temperament and demeanor.” The CCL said she had “good legal ability” and is “praised for her supervisory skills.” The ISBA noted her experience in jury trials, appeals, and employment matters.

fields.name: Democratic primary for 1ST APPELLATE - SIMON VACANCY
Democratic primary for COOK - 3RD SUBCIRCUIT - FLYNN VACANCY
JOHN GARRIDO
fields.bio: John Garrido is a lieutenant in the Chicago Police Department in the 16th District. He has served for 29 years on the police force in various roles, including patrol officer, undercover narcotics officer, and violent crimes detective. He has also been a practicing lawyer since 2006, opening a firm with a fellow police officer. His firm, Garrido & Stoppa, P.C., focuses on probate, general practice, estate planning, and residential real estate. He considers himself an animal advocate and, with his wife, created the Garrido Stray Rescue Foundation.
fields.notable: Garrido ran for 45th Ward alderman in 2011 and 2015, losing both times to Former Ald. John Arena. Garrido sued but lost a defamation case against Arena in 2011. After Arena lost his seat in early 2019, Garrido got involved in a heated [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=2470591039637138&set=a.220352627994335&type=3&theater) spat with him. Garrido also ran unsuccessfully in the 2010 Republican primary for Cook County Board president.
fields.ratingNotes: Garrido was rated not recommended by the bar associations because he did not participate in the evaluation process.

fields.name: BRAD S. TELANDER
fields.bio: Brad Telander works in private practice as a criminal defense attorney. From 1983 to 1991, he was a Cook County assistant state's attorney, prosecuting gang crimes and other felony and misdemeanor cases.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL highlighted Telander’s legal ability and noted that he has “substantial litigation experience.” ISBA said he is considered “a ‘straight shooter’, prepared and unflappable.”

fields.name: LLOYD JAMES BROOKS
fields.bio: Lloyd Brooks was appointed to the Circuit Court in November 2018. Prior to his appointment, Brooks worked in private practice, specializing in consumer protection and mortgage foreclosure defense. Brooks also practiced in insurance law and commercial litigation. He currently oversees cases in the Municipal Division at the Daley Center.
fields.notable: Brooks’ campaign is mostly self-funded. He has loaned his campaign $90,000. Brooks is the Democratic Party’s slated candidate, and has donated $40,000 to the Cook County Democratic Party.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA referenced Brooks’s experience in a high-volume courtroom and his “excellent demeanor.” The CCL said Brooks has a “good grasp of the law and procedure,” and the ISBA cited his “excellent legal knowledge.”

fields.name: JAMES SAMUEL WORLEY
fields.bio: James Samuel Worley is an attorney at Gottreich, Grace & Thompson, where he specializes in family law and DUI criminal defense. Before joining his current firm, he ran his own firm, J. Samuel Worley, LLC. Worley began his legal career as an assistant state’s attorney, and he is currently also an attorney for the Fraternal Order of Police.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA cited Worley’s “broad experience in both criminal law and domestic relations.” The CCL noted there has been “high praise for his legal knowledge, ability, and experience.” However, the ISBA said “concerns were raised by some attorneys about the depth and breadth of his experience and his minimal experience with jury trials and complex litigation.”

fields.name: Appellate candidate’s heated letter causes stir among party members, fellow judges
SHEREE DESIREE HENRY
fields.bio: Sheree Henry was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in July 2019. Prior to her appointment, Henry worked as an assistant public defender for two decades. Before that, she spent four years as an assistant public guardian, representing children in abuse and neglect cases. Henry currently oversees traffic cases at the Daley Center.
fields.notable: Henry served in the Illinois Army National Guard for eight years.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA mentioned her “passionate advocacy on behalf of her clients” during her time as a public defender prior to her appointment as judge. The CCL referenced Henry’s “substantial bench and jury litigation experience.” The ISBA noted her “sensitivity to racial and ethnic diversity issues.” She was the only candidate of four running for the Murphy Gorman vacancy to receive a qualified rating from all three bar associations.

fields.name: 3rd Subcircuit
fields.description: The 3rd subcircuit includes parts of the Southwest Side, including Midway, Marquette Park, Beverly and Mt. Greenwood. It also includes the southwest suburbs of Burbank, Hometown, and Evergreen Park, and the northeast corner of Oak Lawn.

fields.name: MARY THERESE QUINN
fields.bio: Mary Quinn spent over two decades in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office, where she prosecuted a wide variety of felony cases. She currently works in private practice as a criminal defense attorney. Quinn ran three previous times for a Cook County Circuit Court seat in the 15th subcircuit but failed to win the Democratic primary on each occasion.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA commended Quinn’s criminal trial experience and legal ability. The ISBA said, “She is considered by other attorneys to be knowledgeable and well-prepared with high character and integrity.” The CCL noted her “good legal ability with litigation experience on criminal law matters.”

fields.name: CCL Qualified
fields.description: The candidate has demonstrated the abilities required of a judge on the relevant court in the areas considered (e.g. fairness, competence, conduct, independence, integrity/character).

fields.name: MEGAN KATHLEEN MULAY
fields.bio: Megan Mulay has spent her career as an assistant state’s attorney in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office. She is currently assigned to the criminal prosecutions bureau in the Leighton Criminal Courthouse. Mulay currently oversees the prosecution and management of over 300 active felony cases.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA commended Mulay’s extensive trial experience and legal knowledge. The CCL called Mulay a “highly respected prosecutor” and praised her integrity and courtroom skills. The ISBA praised both her experience in complex matters and her temperament, but noted that a few attorneys “did raise some concerns over her diligence in responding to discovery requests.”

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK - 10TH SUBCIRCUIT - ALLEN VACANCY
Republican primary for COOK - 13TH SUBCIRCUIT - KULYS HOFFMAN VACANCY
ANGEL GARCIA
fields.bio: Angel Garcia has practiced as a private attorney since his admission to the bar in 2011. His firm, Garcia Group Law, focuses on a range of legal areas, including criminal defense, administrative law, and futures and derivatives. Before becoming a lawyer, Garcia worked at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Garcia has been active in Republican Party politics for a number of years. He ran unsuccessfully for Cook County Clerk in 2010.
fields.ratingNotes: Garcia did not participate in the CBA or CCL evaluation process. The ISBA found him not recommended because he has less than ten years of practice experience.

fields.name: 15th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 15th subcircuit covers the south and southwest suburbs of Flossmoor, Chicago Heights, Matteson, Oak Forest, Tinley Park, Oak Forest and Orland Park.

fields.name: CORY ELI OSHITA
fields.bio: Corey Oshita has worked in private practice for his entire career and currently owns a law firm where he practices in family law, bankruptcy and personal injury, among other areas. Oshita has also been a hearing officer for the Chicago Board of Education since 2009.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA wrote that Oshita is “an experienced practitioner well regarded for his knowledge of the law, legal ability, work ethic, fine temperament, and calm demeanor.” The CCL cited concerns about “the depth and breadth of his practice, particularly in light of the relatively small number of years that he has been a lawyer.” The ISBA echoed these concerns, noting “his lack of jury and complex trial experience.”

fields.name: TIESHA L. SMITH
fields.bio: Tiesha L. Smith has worked in the Cook County Public Defender’s Office since 2010. Before that, she practiced in insurance defense litigation and foreclosure mediation and worked as an attorney for Chicago Public Schools. Smith ran unsuccessfully for the Cook County Circuit Court 2nd subcircuit in 2018.
fields.ratingNotes: Smith was rated not recommended by the bar associations because she did not participate in the evaluation process.

fields.name: HEATHER ANNE KENT
fields.bio: Heather Kent has spent her career as an assistant Cook County state’s attorney. Kent, who was admitted to the Illinois bar in 2006, is currently assigned to the felony trial division, after previously trying cases in both misdemeanor and child protection courtrooms.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted her “excellent demeanor,” the CCL referenced her “high integrity” and the ISBA said she “is considered to be prepared, even-handed and of high character.”

fields.name: Chicago lawyer running for judge accused of withholding evidence
7th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 7th subcircuit extends west along the Eisenhower Expressway from the West Loop to the west suburbs of Berwyn, Forest Park and River Forest (but does not include Oak Park). It includes the West Side neighborhoods of Garfield Park, North Lawndale, Homan Square and Austin, and part of West Humboldt Park.

fields.name: Resurrected: Five Cook County judicial election losers rebound quickly
ELIZABETH "BETH" RYAN
fields.bio: Elizabeth Ryan is currently an attorney at the law office of Elizabeth C. Ryan, specializing in personal injury law. She has been a practicing attorney since 2006. She previously worked at Newman Boyer & Statham and clerked for Cook County Circuit Court Judge Martin Agran.
fields.notable: Ryan has filed a notice of self-funding, and she and her husband, Clancy, have contributed over $150,000 to her campaign.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA stated that Ryan is “well regarded by her peers and by the judges before whom she has appeared.” The CCL noted her experience in complex matters. The ISBA said, “A few [attorneys] questioned the extent of her experience in complex matters,” but also concluded, “She is considered to be very professional, diligent and punctual, with a good temperament and high ethical standards.”

fields.name: THOMAS J. CONDON, JR.
fields.bio: Thomas J. Condon Jr. is a lawyer in private practice at the Chicago-based firm of Peterson, Johnson & Murray, where he has specialized in personal injury law and business litigation for the past four years. Condon worked for a number of firms previously, and has a combined 17 years of legal experience, including 4 years as assistant department counsel for the Chicago Department of Buildings.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Condon’s extensive work in litigation and government practice, and the CCL wrote that he “is considered to have good legal ability with substantial experience in a variety of legal areas.”

fields.name: 10th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 10th subcircuit covers much of the Northwest Side, including North Center, Ravenswood, Albany Park, Jefferson Park, Norwood Park and Edison Park. It also includes parts of Niles and Park Ridge.

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK - 12TH SUBCIRCUIT - HANLON VACANCY
9th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 9th subcircuit covers the North Side neighborhoods of Rogers Park and West Ridge and the north suburbs of Evanston, Skokie, Lincolnwood and Wilmette. It is home to the court's Skokie court house.

fields.name: Lawsuit alleges judicial candidate helped Detective Guevara frame an innocent man
fields.description: Frank DiFranco, who is running for judge in the 12th subcircuit Republican primary, is accused of knowingly taking a false confession that sent a man to prison for 27 years.

fields.name: BONNIE CAROL McGRATH
fields.bio: Bonnie McGrath has worked in private practice throughout her legal career. According to a written statement to *Injustice Watch* in 2018, she has “prosecuted municipal violations” for Cook County and practiced in all areas of the Cook County Circuit Court. She also writes a personal [blog](http://www.chicagonow.com/mom-think-poignant) about politics and other topics of interest. This is McGrath’s fifth run for the bench.
fields.notable: McGrath was identified to *Injustice Watch* by people involved in judicial races as having run in the past as a “sham candidate,” intended to siphon votes from one candidate to help another judicial hopeful.  Until January, McGrath had reported raising no money, was not appearing at candidate events and had no campaign website. In a statement to *Injustice Watch*, McGrath said she is “running for judge to become a judge!”
fields.ratingNotes: McGrath was rated not recommended by the bar associations because she did not participate in the evaluation process.

fields.name: DEIDRE BAUMANN
fields.bio: Baumann runs her own practice, where she specializes in civil rights litigation, personal injury and employment discrimination. She started her career in a boutique law firm that specialized in First Amendment law. She previously worked as an arbitrator for the Circuit Court of Cook County.
fields.notable: Baumann has been heavily involved in the LGBTQ community throughout her career. According to her campaign site, she is currently on the board of the Lesbian and Gay Bar Association of Chicago and serves as vice chair of the Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity Committee of the Illinois State Bar Association.
fields.ratingNotes: Ratings for Bauman were mixed. The CBA mentioned “significant concerns” raised to them of Baumann’s professionalism, organizational skills, and knowledge of the law. The CCL said Baumann was reported to be a “respected attorney with substantial litigation experience” and the ISBA noted, “she is considered diligent and professional with strong writing skills.”

fields.name: A first for Illinois: An openly transgender judicial candidate
DANIEL ALEXANDER TREVINO
fields.bio: Since 2018, Trevino has been an associate judge for the Cook County Circuit Court, where he hears cases in the Domestic Relations Division. Prior to taking the bench, he worked as a partner in the Chicago office of the law firm Hinshaw & Culbertson. Trevino focused on products liability and transportation litigation while working in private practice.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA praised Trevino’s legal knowledge and experience. The ISBA cited his “character, impartiality, extensive knowledge of the law, and his ability to handle complex litigation.” The CCL said he has an “exceptional temperament – a strong advocate but always professional in his dealings with opposing counsel.”

fields.name: SHARON O. JOHNSON
fields.bio: Sharon Johnson was first elected as a Cook County Circuit Court judge in 2010, beating a five-person field in the primary from the 1st subcircuit. Johnson is assigned to the domestic relations division at the Markham Courthouse, which handles divorce, child custody and support matters. Previously, she worked for more than a decade in private practice, focusing on real estate, corporate and family law. Johnson ran unsuccessfully for a seat on the Illinois Appellate Court in 2014.
fields.notable: In her first years on the bench, Johnson received negative ratings from bar associations, which cited issues with her temperament and court management. But by the time she successfully ran for retention in 2016 Johnson’s ratings improved, with praise for both her work ethic, legal ability, and thoroughness of her preparation.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA reported that Johnson is “bright and prepared with good legal knowledge” and said she is “patient with litigants and has a calm demeanor.” The CCL said she is “an excellent jurist” and the CBA praised her experience, work ethic, diligence and demeanor.

fields.name: JULIE BESS AIMEN
fields.bio: Julie Aimen is a civil rights, criminal defense and family law attorney who began her legal career in 1984 and runs a private practice in downtown Chicago. Aimen was the first woman president of the Illinois Association for Criminal Defense Lawyers, and is also a past member of the Board of Governors of the Chicago Council of Lawyers. Before her legal career, Aimen was a social worker in Cook County, working with war veterans, victims of domestic violence, substance abusers and people with mental illness, according to her campaign website.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA praised Aimen’s “substantial” experience in complex matters, and the CBA highlighted her “knowledge of the law, legal ability, and calm demeanor.” The CCL emphasized her pro bono work and described her as “a zealous advocate for her clients. Her integrity is unquestioned.”

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK - 8TH SUBCIRCUIT - GUBIN VACANCY
THOMAS PETER KOUGIAS
fields.bio: Thomas Peter Kougias is a private defense attorney in both criminal and civil cases. He previously spent over two decades working as a Cook County assistant state’s attorney, including time as a prosecutor in the juvenile justice bureau and the felony trial division. He ran unsuccessfully for another 9th subcircuit vacancy in 2016.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Kougias’s “extensive criminal trial experience” and legal knowledge. The ISBA expressed concern about “his lack of civil experience, organizational skills and temperament.” The CCL contended that he “he has not distinguished himself as a prosecutor” and said that “many lawyers say that he lacks sufficient trial management skills to become a judge and some lawyers say that he is not always punctual.”

fields.name: AMANDA "MANDY" PILLSBURY
fields.bio: Amanda Pillsbury has worked as an assistant Cook County state’s attorney for her entire 15-year legal career. She currently serves in the felony trial division.
fields.notable: Pillsbury unsuccessfully ran for a circuit court seat in 2018. In that election, multiple bar associations made a mention of her temperament. The ISBA found opinions on her diligence and temperament were “divided,” and the CCL said she could be “abrasive with opposing counsel.” Both these organizations found her not qualified in 2018.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL rated Pillsbury not qualified again this year after some respondents questioned her diligence, and once again claimed she had occasionally been “abrasive with opposing counsel.” The ISBA also said, “opinions on her diligence and temperament were also divided” and questioned her experience in complex matters. The CBA rated her qualified due to her “legal knowledge and experience.”

fields.name: Democratic primary for 1ST SUPREME - FREEMAN VACANCY
Cook County prosecutor Gerber coaxed wrongful conviction, appeal states
Democratic primary for COOK - 9TH SUBCIRCUIT - LUCKMAN VACANCY
DANIEL EPSTEIN
fields.bio: Epstein is the youngest candidate in the race, and also the most unorthodox. He was admitted to the Illinois bar in 2015, and is the only candidate who has no judicial experience. He was an associate at the Chicago law firm Jenner & Block, where he handled several cases pro bono, until he began his run for office. Epstein has focused his campaign not on the legal opinions that the state high court delivers, but on the potential for the court to accomplish reform by enacting new court rules, such as expanding the discovery available to defendants and reforming cash bail throughout the state.
fields.notable: Epstein was ineligible to receive favorable recommendations from the various bar associations, which all set a minimum number of years practicing law that Epstein lacks.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA and CCL praised Epstein’s intelligence and his platform for reform, but all three bar associations said he lacks the requisite experience for the Supreme Court.

fields.name: MARCIA O'BRIEN CONWAY
fields.bio: Marcia O’Brien Conway has spent most of her career as an assistant state’s attorney in Cook County. She currently works in the Real Estate Tax Division and previously worked on corporate transactions. Prior to joining the State’s Attorney’s Office, Conway focused on real estate issues in private practice.
fields.notable: Marcia O’Brien Conway was originally Marcia Marie Organ. At least one of her name changes comes from the fact that she was married for a time to Raymond Nimrod. It’s unclear where Conway and O’Brien comes from.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA and ISBA noted Conway’s trial experience and diligence. The CCL rated her “well qualified” and wrote that she “was often cited as an expert in real estate and taxation law.” The Council also praised her work ethic and temperament.

fields.name: WENDELIN "WENDI" DeLOACH
fields.bio: Wendelin DeLoach is an attorney in private practice, where she works in a wide range of legal areas, including criminal defense, family law and personal injury. She has been licensed to practice in Illinois since 2007 and practiced in Colorado in the early 1990s.
fields.notable: DeLoach was given a 30 day suspension in Colorado in 1997 for representing a client in a murder case when she had previously represented a co-defendant in a separate matter. She used that relationship to visit the co-defendant several times in jail without his lawyer’s knowledge or approval.
fields.ratingNotes: DeLoach was rated not recommended by the bar associations because she did not participate in the evaluation process.

fields.name: After diversity concerns, appointed subcircuit judge declines to run
JOHN G. MULROE
fields.bio: John Mulroe was appointed to fill a vacancy on the Cook County Circuit Court 10th subcircuit in June 2019. Prior to his appointment, Mulroe served as a state senator for nearly a decade. He began his career as an assistant state’s attorney for six years before spending over two decades in private practice. He has also been a hearing officer for the City of Chicago and an arbitrator in the Cook County Mandatory Arbitration Program. Mulroe ran unsuccessfully for the 10th subcircuit in 2008.
fields.notable: As a state senator, Mulroe was chairman of the Senate Public Health Committee and received thousands of dollars in contributions from pharmaceutical companies and industry groups.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA called Mulroe “a dedicated public servant” and praised his legal knowledge, experience and temperament. The ISBA said he is “a well-rounded attorney who treats all with respect.” The CCL also cited his trial skills, integrity and temperament.

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK CIRCUIT- FORD VACANCY
Democratic primary for COOK CIRCUIT- SHEEHAN, K. VACANCY
U. O'NEAL
fields.bio: U. O’Neal has worked as an attorney and principal partner in his own law firm since 1993. He has practiced in a range of different areas of law, including corporate, criminal defense and civil rights. O’Neal is also a certified mandatory arbitrator for the circuit courts of Cook County. He previously ran as Ubi O’Neal in the 2018 Democratic primary for Cook County’s 2nd subcircuit and lost. When he was admitted to the Illinois bar, O’Neal was known as Ubochi Osuji.
fields.notable: O’Neal was censured for legal misconduct by the Illinois Supreme Court in 1999, after he directed someone to fraudulently endorse a settlement check so that he could be paid for his work. The Attorney Registration and Disciplinary Commission chose censure over more severe remedies, noting that “his improper conduct is attributable to lack of experience and poor judgment rather than an intent to deny any party a share of the settlement proceeds.”
fields.ratingNotes: O’Neal was rated not recommended by the bar associations because he did not participate in the evaluation process.

fields.name: TERESA MOLINA
fields.bio: Teresa Molina was appointed to a vacancy on the Cook County Circuit Court in July 2019, and she currently works in the First Municipal Division, where she oversees traffic cases. Prior to her appointment, she led real estate prosecutions at the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation. For the first 15 years of her legal career, Molina was a Cook County assistant state’s attorney, where she worked in the felony trial division, the grand jury unit, and the felony review unit.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Molina’s “significant trial experience” and legal knowledge. The ISBA said, “She received favorable comments regarding her temperament, diligence and integrity.” The CCL noted, “She is considered to be a good jurist in the limited time she has been on the bench.”

fields.name: 16 judge candidates fail to win bar support, but will voters care?
Palatine committeeman’s judicial bid appears to violate ethics rules
CCL Well Qualified
fields.description: The candidate has demonstrated the abilities required of a judge on the relevant court in the areas considered (e.g. fairness, competence, conduct, independence, integrity/character), and excellence in most areas.

fields.name: CHRIS STACEY
fields.bio: Chris Stacey has worked in private practice throughout his legal career, primarily in the areas of tort and commercial litigation. Stacey has run for judge once before, in 1998, when he [highlighted](https://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/playing-an-angle/Content?oid=895665) his musical background. He has served on the board of Cabrini Green Legal Aid.
fields.notable: Stacey is the Democratic party’s slated candidate. He has loaned his campaign more than $170,000 and has donated more than $40,000 to the Cook County Democratic Party.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA wrote Stacey is “highly regarded for his knowledge of the law, legal ability, and excellent demeanor.” The ISBA wrote, “Attorneys overwhelmingly praised him for his legal knowledge, intelligence, professionalism, and fairness.” The CCL noted, “He is exceptionally active in community affairs.”

fields.name: Republican primary for COOK - 12TH SUBCIRCUIT - HANLON VACANCY
ARTHUR D. SUTTON
fields.bio: Arthur Sutton is  an attorney in private practice, where he practices civil litigation and criminal defense. He has previously worked in a variety of roles in the Department of Corrections, including time as a correctional officer. He began his legal career as a Cook County public defender in the mid-1990s. He previously ran for judge in 2006.
fields.notable:
Sutton resigned from his position as Deputy Director of the Parole Division of the Illinois Department of Corrections in February 2015 after failing to secure his government-issued gun on two occasions. The first came in 2014 when his son, then 17, took the gun and shot himself in the ankle, and the second happened in February 2015 when his son once again took the gun and used it in an armed robbery in which someone was shot in the leg.

In 2003, Sutton received a 90-day stayed suspension from the Illinois Supreme Court. The Attorney Registration and Disciplinary Commission concluded that Sutton had violated multiple ethical policies by improperly managing settlement money and mixing his personal funds with settlement funds.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA raised “concerns about his diligence, attention to detail, and depth and breadth of practice experience.” The ISBA and CCL complemented his legal ability and temperament.

fields.name: TIMOTHY PATRICK CARTER
fields.bio: Timothy Patrick Carter worked as an assistant Cook County state’s attorney for 16 years, spending the bulk of his time in the felony trial division, before becoming a private criminal defense attorney in 2012.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA wrote, “He has extensive jury and bench trial experience including in complex matters.” The CBA and CCL also praised his experience, legal ability and temperament.

fields.name: P. SCOTT NEVILLE, JR.
fields.bio: Neville was appointed to the Illinois Supreme Court in 2018, following the retirement of Charles Freeman, the only person of color ever to win election to a seat on the state’s highest court. Neville was first appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in 1999 and elected the following year. In 2004, he was appointed to the Illinois Appellate Court, and he won election to that seat in 2012. Prior to becoming a judge, Neville spent years in private practice, and for several years one of his partners was Nathaniel Howse, now a competitor for the Supreme Court seat. Last year Neville authored the opinion for a unanimous state Supreme Court ruling that sentences of more than 40 years for juveniles are effectively life sentences, triggering additional protections for youth.
fields.notable: As a Supreme Court justice, Neville has taken an active role to ensure all courtrooms provide a means to transcribe proceedings and in protecting the rights of litigants who are in court without a lawyer.
fields.ratingNotes: All three bar associations praised Neville’s experience and legal knowledge. The CBA said he is “committed to improving the Illinois Courts.” The ISBA said his questions during oral arguments reflect a thorough review of the briefs and that he is considered to be “honest and a straight shooter.” The CCL cited praise from “social justice advocates” and Neville’s “understanding that judges can be active supporters of reforms aimed at improving the effectiveness and fairness of our courts.”

fields.name: MICHAEL P. GERBER
fields.bio: Michael Perry Gerber was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court 13th subcircuit in June 2019 and currently is assigned to the Rolling Meadows Courthouse. Gerber had been the longest-serving prosecutor in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office when he was first appointed by the state Supreme Court to fill a Circuit Court vacancy. Gerber ran for but lost the 2018 Republican primary for that seat.
fields.notable: Gerber was found by judges in two separate cases to have committed misconduct as an assistant state’s attorney that led to wrongful convictions. One involved a murder and arson conviction that went to retrial after evidence emerged that cast doubt on the defendant’s guilt. The second conviction was later overturned by a Cook County judge who found that Gerber, who prosecuted both cases, made statements during closing arguments at the second trial that contradicted what the jury had been told at the first trial. Then, in 2018, an appellate court panel found that Gerber had won a murder conviction of an innocent defendant in part by shifting the jury’s attention from the lack of physical evidence, to whether the defense attorney, during trial, had maligned the police. In a recent conversation with *Injustice Watch*, Gerber denied knowingly participating in any misconduct and noted that P. Scott Neville, the judge who wrote the appellate opinion in the second case, voted in favor of his recent judicial appointment.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA and ISBA praised Gerber’s experience and legal knowledge. The CCL reported he is an “outstanding practitioner with very good legal ability and temperament,” but called the misconduct allegations “exceptionally serious.” The Council said its qualified rating was “a close call.”

fields.name: MICHAEL O'MALLEY
fields.bio: Michael O’Malley has served as an assistant Cook County state’s attorney for the past 14 years. He currently works in the office’s civil rights and torts division. He previously worked in the special prosecutions bureau, where he prosecuted public corruption, and has prosecuted child sex crimes. Prior to becoming a lawyer, O’Malley was a financial analyst for JPMorgan Chase. O’Malley ran unsuccessfully for judge in 2016 and 2018.
fields.notable: O’Malley’s campaign is largely self-funded. He has loaned his campaign committee more than $68,000.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted that he is “highly respected by his colleagues.” The ISBA wrote, “Attorneys report that he is a straight shooter with excellent legal knowledge and is always prepared.”

fields.name: SHELLY A. HARRIS
fields.bio: Shelly Harris has been a judge since 2000, when he was appointed to a vacancy on the Cook County Circuit Court. Harris had previously been a lawyer in private practice. In 2002, Harris was defeated when he sought election to a full term on the court, with one major bar association citing concerns regarding his temperament. The Illinois Supreme Court reappointed Harris to another Circuit Court vacancy in 2005. In 2010 the supreme court appointed Harris to serve on the Illinois Appellate Court, and then gave him another appellate appointment in 2013. In 2014 Harris ran for and won a full term, defeating two other candidates in the March primary.
fields.notable:
State records show Harris has loaned his campaign [nearly $2 million](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2020/4-7-million-race-illinois-supreme-court/), an amount that dwarfs his opponents. Money has been an issue in Harris’s past races. In 2002 the [Chicago Tribune reported](https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-2002-09-06-0209060172-story.html) that Harris’s two adult sons had each given $25,000 to support the campaign of Lisa Madigan in her race for state attorney general, among the largest individual donations she had received. Madigan’s father, Illinois House Speaker and Democratic Party Chairman Michael Madigan, had supported Harris’s election effort, and Harris ran with party support. Harris told the Tribune then that his sons gave the money independently of him.
*Injustice Watch* [reported](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2020/illinois-supreme-court-candidate-harris-accused-of-ethical-breach-involving-nephews-case/) that Harris tried to intervene in a case involving his nephew by approaching a fellow Appellate Court judge who was set to hear the case. Harris did not respond to multiple requests for comment,
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA said Harris is regarded for his “diligence in preparing for oral arguments and issuing timely opinions, and good judicial demeanor.” The CCL similarly said he was “knowledgeable and hard-working” and attentive during oral arguments. The ISBA raised concerns about his demeanor.

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK CIRCUIT- MURPHY GORMAN VACANCY
JONATHAN CLARK GREEN
fields.bio: Jonathan Clark Green is a supervising attorney in the Chicago Department of Law who focuses on civil litigation. Green was first licensed in Illinois in 1986, and has been in his current position since 2003. He has worked on implementing the city’s new consent decree for police officers, and represented the city and police in lawsuits. Previously, Green was an assistant attorney general in the office of the Illinois Attorney General.
fields.notable: Green’s division of the Law Department has in the past been criticized and sanctioned for withholding evidence in lawsuits against the city police. *Injustice Watch* [reported on those complaints](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2018/chicago-law-department-police-running-for-judge-accused-of-withholding-evidence/) in 2018, when Green previously ran for a Circuit Court seat. Green responded that he has never been personally sanctioned by any court and says he was not personally involved in the particular discovery issues that we previously reported on.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA and CCL praised Green’s broad legal experience and his legal ability. The ISBA wrote that a few attorneys “expressed concerns over ongoing discovery issues in federal court in civil rights cases with the City’s Law Department, and his role and responsibility concerning those issues.”

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK - 13TH SUBCIRCUIT - KULYS HOFFMAN VACANCY
Democratic primary for COOK CIRCUIT- PATTI VACANCY
JILL ROSE QUINN
fields.bio: Jill Quinn is an attorney in private practice, working in a wide range of areas of law, including bankruptcy, family law, and criminal defense. Before running her own practice, Quinn worked for the Village Attorney of Glen Ellyn and as an arbitrator in both DuPage and Cook counties. She ran unsuccessfully for a Cook County Circuit Court 10th subcircuit seat in 2018.
fields.notable: If elected, Quinn would become the first transgender judge in Illinois.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL touted Quinn’s “substantial litigation experience in more complex legal areas,” and the CBA noted her “outstanding demeanor and temperament.” The ISBA said, “She has limited criminal jury experience but many civil bench trials and has handled some appellate matters.”

fields.name: DAN WALSH
fields.bio: Dan Walsh has worked as an assistant Cook County public defender for most of his career. He represents defendants in felony cases at the Maywood Courthouse. Walsh, who was admitted to the bar in 2001, earlier worked for the State Appellate Defender.
fields.ratingNotes: Walsh was rated not recommended by the bar associations because he did not participate in the evaluation process.

fields.name: Democratic primary for 1ST APPELLATE - NEVILLE, JR. VACANCY
JAMES PATRICK CRAWLEY
fields.bio: Crawley works at Kennedy and Associates, P.C., a Chicago law firm, where he specializes in wrongful death and product liability litigation for both plaintiffs and defendants. This is Crawley’s second judicial run after an unsuccessful bid in 2014.
fields.notable: Crawley has been an active member of the LGBTQ community. Among other positions, he was previously on the LGBT Citizens Advisory Committee for the Chicago Police Department.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA said Crawley is diligent and experienced, and the CCL called Crawley “exceptionally knowledgeable.” The ISBA called him “honest” and a “fair attorney.”

fields.name: AUDREY VICTORIA COSGROVE
fields.currentJob: Deputy Chief General Counsel at Illinois Lottery
fields.bio: Prior to joining the Illinois Lottery, Cosgrove worked as an attorney for the Illinois Department of Labor. She and her husband, Thomas Cosgrove, run a law firm specializing in real estate and criminal defense. Cosgrove spent her early career working as an assistant public defender, where she worked in child protection court before eventually moving into felony court. She has also worked as an administrative law judge with the Illinois State Police Merit Board and the Illinois State Board of Education.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL said Cosgrove has a variety of experiences, “including litigation in more complex matters earlier in her career.” The CBA and ISBA noted her knowledge of the law and diverse practice experience.

fields.name: CCL Not Recommended
fields.description: The candidate refused to submit their credentials, but the council is not aware of credible information that would justify a “not qualified” rating.

fields.name: JAMES T. DERICO, JR.
fields.bio: James Derico was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in December 2018, and serves in the Municipal Division. Prior to his appointment, he spent much of his career in private practice, where he specialized in business, real estate and tax law. Derico also previously volunteered for Chicago Volunteer Legal Services, an organization that offers pro bono legal representation to low-income clients in the Chicago area.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL praised Derico’s pro bono work, and mentioned his substantial litigation experience. The ISBA said the majority of people reported Derico to be “even keeled and personable,” although “a few expressed concerns that at times he could be uncivil.” The ISBA still rated Derico qualified, saying, “He is generally considered to be fair and impartial.”

fields.name: JOHN O'MEARA
fields.bio: John O’Meara is currently an administrative law judge for the Illinois Department of Labor. He was appointed as a Circuit Court judge in the 4th subcircuit in 2016, but he was unseated in the 2018 Democratic primary. After graduating from law school, O’Meara worked as an assistant corporation counsel for the City of Chicago. Prior to his appointment to the bench, O’Meara worked as an attorney in private practice for nearly two decades, where he specialized in civil litigation.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA ranked O’Meara highly qualified for his excellent temperament, extensive experience and knowledge of the law. The CCL cited O’Meara’s experience in complex matters and the ISBA said O’Meara is “professional with high integrity.”

fields.name: JOHN GRIFFIN
fields.bio: John C. Griffin has served by appointment on the Illinois Appellate Court since 2018. He worked for years in a law firm co-founded by his father, James L. Griffin, specializing in property law. He was appointed to fill a Circuit Court vacancy in 2008 and first was elected to a full term in 2010; he then won retention in 2016. Griffin spent years in the court’s law division, serving as a supervising judge in large commercial cases. He won praise there for being hard-working and knowledgeable.
fields.notable: In 2018 Griffin wrote the opinion for a unanimous panel ordering former Cook County Assessor Joseph Berrios, the former Cook County Democratic party chairman, to make public records showing how homes were valued for tax purposes.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted that Griffin is hardworking and praised his experience and ability. The ISBA said, “His written opinions are clear and understandable, and he is respectful to all.” The CCL also lauded his written opinions and said he “is a frequent contributor to judicial training sessions.”

fields.name: Former public defender
fields.description: History as a public defender is an important qualification in terms of experience. According to Professor Tonja Jacobi, who studies judicial politics at Northwestern University's Pritzker School of Law, former defense attorneys may be more likely to be more sympathetic to defendants in criminal cases.

fields.name: MICHAEL ALAN STROM
fields.bio: Michael Alan Strom was appointed in January 2019 to fill a Cook County Circuit Court vacancy. He currently presides over municipal cases at the Daley Center in Chicago. Strom was previously Chief Judge Timothy Evans’ staff attorney for about five years. A licensed attorney since 1977, Strom had also operated his own private practice, where he specialized in workers’ compensation and personal injury law, representing clients ranging from renewable energy providers to the City of Chicago. Strom made unsuccessful bids for subcircuit seats in 2004 and 2014.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA noted Strom’s “extensive experience as a trial lawyer in civil matters.” The CCL praised his legal ability and temperament, as well as his community involvement.

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK CIRCUIT- O'BRIEN VACANCY
STEVE DEMITRO
fields.bio: Steve Demitro has worked in private practice throughout his career, focusing on personal injury law. He previously served as chairman of the Education Funding Advisory Board for the state of Illinois. Demitro has done arbitration work for the Circuit Court of Cook County. He ran unsuccessfully for the Circuit Court in 2012.
fields.notable: Demitro, the son of immigrants, dropped out of high school, but -- after a chance meeting with a lawyer -- completed his GED, graduated from college and law school, and passed the bar.
fields.ratingNotes: Demitro was rated not recommended by the bar associations because he did not participate in the evaluation process.

fields.name: Cook County judicial candidate Arthur Sutton has history of disciplinary issues
JOE GUMP
fields.bio: Joe Gump retired recently after serving for 30 years as a Cook County public defender, the past several years as felony trial attorney in the Rolling Meadows courthouse. He was active for years in the union representing public defenders. Since retiring, Gump has gone into private practice.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL said Gump is “praised for being a zealous advocate” and noted his substantial experience with complex litigation. The ISBA said, “Attorneys and judges reported that he writes well and has excellent research skills, is sensitive to diversity and even keeled.” They also mentioned a few concerns about punctuality.

fields.name: Negative ratings
fields.description: Bar associations provide some of the most unbiased information for assessing the qualifications of potential judges. These bodies interview candidates and assess their personal and professional histories. They also ask judges and attorneys who have worked with or appeared before the candidates about their temperament and professionalism. Ratings are based on qualifications, not political views, and negative ratings are a strong signal that a candidate could make a poor judge. Candidates who choose not to participate in the ratings process automatically receive negative ratings.

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK CIRCUIT- McCARTHY VACANCY
Sham candidates for judge: an election secret you’re not supposed to know about
HEATHER MULLIGAN BEGLEY
fields.bio: Heather Begley is an associate at Cunningham, Meyer & Vedrine, where she focuses on medical malpractice defense. She previously worked as a personal injury lawyer.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA said Begley is “hardworking” and has an “excellent temperament.” ISBA praised her “professionalism, knowledge, integrity, and level-headedness.” CCL said she has substantial litigation experience and works well with opposing attorneys.

fields.name: LIAM KELLY
fields.bio: Liam Kelly is an attorney at the law office of Robert Rascia, where he practices criminal defense law. Kelly was admitted to the bar in Illinois in 2011. He is also admitted to practice in Wisconsin, Indiana, Michigan, and New Jersey. He has been active in the 39th Ward Democratic party.
fields.ratingNotes: Kelly did not participate in the CBA and CCL evaluation process, and the ISBA noted he does not have the minimum ten years of experience.

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK - 1ST SUBCIRCUIT - BROOKS VACANCY
Judge candidate Anne Shaw had real estate license reprimanded for deceptive practices
REGINA ANN MESCALL
fields.bio: Regina Ann Mescall has worked as an assistant Cook County state’s attorney since 2007. She currently oversees cases as a first chair felony trial assistant, responsible for the active murder cases in Cook County. Mescall began her career as an assistant district attorney in Albuquerque, New Mexico, where she prosecuted crimes against children for over 5 years.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA praised Mescall’s “extensive experience” and noted that she has tried “many high profile cases.” The ISBA also praised her experience in “serious and complex felonies.” The CCL wrote that she “is considered to have good legal ability and handles some of the most complex matters in the State’s Attorney’s Office.”

fields.name: PERLA TIRADO
fields.currentJob: Supervising attorney at Beyond Legal Aid
fields.bio: Perla Tirado began her career with the Cook County Public Defender’s office, where she defended cases related to traffic violations and domestic violence. She then went into private practice, specializing in criminal defense and immigration law. Tirado currently works as a supervising attorney at Beyond Legal Aid, a non-profit legal aid organization for underserved communities.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL said Tirado has a good temperament and “substantial litigation experience in a variety of areas.” But the CBA and ISBA raised concerns about her lack of experience with complex litigation.

fields.name: CAROLYN J. GALLAGHER
fields.bio:
Carolyn Gallagher became a Cook County Circuit Court judge after winning election in 2016. Before becoming a judge, Gallagher spent several years in private practice, where she gained substantial commercial litigation experience. She also had worked as a legal writing instructor.

Gallagher first ran for a seat on the circuit court in 2014, and finished second among four candidates. She ran again in 2016 and won, defeating the slated candidate and three others. She is assigned to a courtroom in the probate division, which handles wills and administers the estates of the deceased, disabled people and minors.
fields.notable: Gallagher caused a bit of a [stir](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2020/appellate-candidates-heated-letter-causes-stir-among-party-members-fellow-judges/) last year when she circulated a letter challenging statements by a Democratic party consultant.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA praised Gallagher’s knowledge, legal ability, and strong legal writing. The CCL noted her “good temperament with a calm and respectful demeanor on the bench.” But the ISBA cited Gallagher’s lack of judicial experience, saying, “In her relatively brief time on the bench, she has not yet presided over matters of sufficient variety and complexity to enable her to acquire the knowledge and experience needed for advancement to the Appellate Court.”

fields.name: FELICIA H. SIMMONS-STOVALL
fields.currentJob: Enforcement Attorney at the Illinois Securities Department
fields.bio: Felicia H. Simmons-Stovall has worked as an enforcement attorney at the Illinois Securities Department for over a decade. On her campaign website, she describes her role as representing the Illinois Secretary of State against “unscrupulous individuals” who commit financial fraud. In addition to her work in consumer protection, Simmons-Stovall has served as an administrative hearing officer for the Illinois Secretary of State. She has previously run twice for alderman in Chicago’s 15th Ward, and lost both times.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL noted Simmon-Stovall’s “variety of legal experiences” and praised her “professional demeanor.” The CBA and ISBA raised concerns about the “depth and breadth” of her legal experience, noting that she has substantial administrative law experience but limited trial experience.

fields.name: MAURA McMAHON ZELLER
fields.bio: Maura Zeller has been an attorney in Cook County for over 26 years, primarily in the area of child welfare and guardianship litigation. She currently represents children in child custody cases as an appointed child representative and guardian ad litem. Before that, she worked for a decade in the Office of the Public Guardian as an assistant public guardian and child representative. Zeller is the board chair of the Thrive Counseling Center in Oak Park.
fields.ratingNotes: Ratings for McMahon were mixed. The CCL rated Zeller qualified for her substantial litigation experience, although noted her “area of practice is narrow.” The CBA pointed to Zeller’s “excellent temperament.” The ISBA cited “concerns about the depth and breadth of her overall legal experience.”

fields.name: LEVANDER "VAN" SMITH, JR.
fields.bio:
Levander Smith was appointed to a Cook County Circuit Court vacancy in early 2019 and currently oversees cases in the domestic violence division. Late last year, Smith was elected by the Circuit Court judges to serve as an associate judge. That vote left the Circuit Court seat open until the election; Smith is guaranteed to either remain an associate judge or, if elected, return to the Circuit Court. 

Prior to his appointment to the bench, he had two stints as an attorney with the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services, first in the 1990s and then again from 2011 to 2019. In between, he spent four years as a prosecutor, first in St. Louis County and then in Cook County. He was also an assistant attorney general in Missouri, where he worked on worker’s compensation cases.
fields.notable: His campaign is mostly self-funded. He had loaned his campaign over $60,000 as of Dec. 31, 2019. He is the Democratic party’s slated candidate and he has donated $30,000 to the Cook County Democractic Party.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Smith’s “varied practice experience” and work ethic. The ISBA wrote that Smith “has an excellent understanding of the law, is sensitive to all, punctual, diligent, and fair.” The CCL complemented his good temperament and trial skills.

fields.name: 2nd Subcircuit
fields.description: The 2nd subcircuit includes the South Side neighborhoods of Roseland and Pullman and several south suburbs, including Dolton, Riverdale, Dixmoor, Harvey, and Homewood. It is home to the court's Markham Courthouse.

fields.name: JOHN HOURIHANE
fields.bio: John Hourihane has worked in private practice throughout his legal career, specializing in business law. He worked at Murphy & Hourihane until 2018, when he created a personal law firm and began working with Brotschul Potts. Prior to his time as a lawyer, Hourihane spent several years as a financial manager.
fields.notable: Hourihane’s campaign is mostly self-funded. He has loaned his campaign more than $150,000.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA highlighted Hourihane’s “extensive experience in commercial litigation and appellate practice.” The ISBA reported that he is “efficient, fair, and even tempered.” The CCL described him as a “solid practitioner” and praised his trial skills and temperament.

fields.name: JON STROMSTA
fields.bio: Jon Stromsta has been a licensed lawyer in Illinois since 1985. He has worked since 2010 at Enterprise Law Group, where he is a partner focusing on commercial, employment, benefits, real estate, family law, and criminal law litigation. Previously, Stramsta worked in the Office of the State Appellate Defender in the Capital Litigation Division and the Post-Conviction Unit, where he represented clients who had been sentenced to death. Stromsta ran unsuccessfully for 10th subcircuit judge in 2018.
fields.ratingNotes: All three bar associations noted Stromsta’s range of experience in civil and criminal law, at both trial court and appellate court levels. The CBA noted that he is active in community service. The ISBA said he is considered “very smart and trustworthy, with a good demeanor and a higher than average understanding of various areas of law.” The CCL also cited his legal ability and knowledge of the law.

fields.name: MATT FLAMM
fields.bio: Flamm has spent his legal career in private practice, focusing on business, real estate and tax law. He also has substantial experience in Democratic Party organizing and campaigning, including community organizing efforts for President Obama’s campaigns in 2008 and 2012. Until recently, he was the Palatine Township Democratic committeeman, a position he had held since 2014.
fields.notable: Flamm resigned from his position as a Democratic committeeman after *Injustice Watch* [reported](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2020/palatine-committeemans-judicial-bid-appears-to-violate-ethics-rules/) that holding a political office while running for judge is a violation of the judicial ethics rules.
fields.ratingNotes: All three bar associations cited Flamm’s legal knowledge, ability, and experience, and the CCL and ISBA noted that he is a “go to” person in the field of real estate tax law. The ISBA also noted his community service and “very good temperament.” The CBA praised Flamm’s “excellent demeanor.”

fields.name: JOSEPH CHICO
fields.bio: Joseph Chico has worked in private practice throughout his career. He practices in a wide range of areas, including family, personal injury, and criminal defense law. He also works as a hearing officer with the Chicago Housing Authority and as an administrative law judge with the City of Chicago. This is his third run for the bench after losing the Democratic primaries in subcircuit races in 2000 and 2010.
fields.notable: Joseph Chico is cousins with Gery Chico, who ran for mayor of Chicago in 2011 and 2019.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA rated Chico as qualified, complementing his legal knowledge, ability, and demeanor. The CCL said “his career lacks substantial litigation experience in more complex matters,” while still complementing his legal ability and temperament. The ISBA also noted Chico’s “limited experience in jury trials and complex legal matters.”

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK - 3RD SUBCIRCUIT - MURPHY VACANCY
MICHAEL B. HYMAN
fields.currentJob: Serving as Appellate Court judge by assignment
fields.bio: Michael Hyman has been a Cook County Circuit judge since 2006 and, since 2013, has served by assignment as an Illinois Appellate Court judge. Hyman spent years in private practice, and has served as president of the Chicago Bar Association and the Illinois Judges Association. He is the editor-in-chief of the bar association magazine, the CBA Record, for which he regularly writes.
fields.notable: Hyman has often divided with colleagues in opinions in criminal cases, writing opinions in support of the rights of the accused for split majorities or in dissent. Last October he [dissented when an appellate panel](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2019/illinois-appellate-court-rejects-ordinance-banning-detention-of-10-12-year-olds/) ruled that a Cook County judge could order the detention of a 13-year old, despite a county ordinance that forbade such detentions. In the past year, Hyman has authored opinions for divided courts striking down a conviction that followed a lineup [made suspect by](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2019/illinois-appeals-court-frowns-at-lineup-with-one-suspect-matching-description/) the defendant’s clothing; a gun conviction that followed a police search that [lacked sufficient cause](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2019/in-two-cases-illinois-appeals-judges-split-on-protections-in-criminal-cases/); and challenged the constitutionality of Chicago police arrests based on “[investigative alerts](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2019/illinois-appeals-court-chicago-police-cannot-decide-on-probable-cause-without-judicial-review/).”
fields.ratingNotes: Hyman was highly praised by all three of the bar associations. The CBA cited his “knowledge of the law, integrity, legal experience, work ethic, and excellent writing skills.” The ISBA said, “Attorneys overwhelmingly praised his legal knowledge, intelligence and preparation.” He is the only one of the candidates for any of the judgeships–from Circuit Court to Supreme Court–to receive a highly qualified rating from the CCL, which cited his temperament and professionalism.

fields.name: SONDRA NICOLE DENMARK
fields.bio: Sondra Denmark was appointed to the 2nd subcircuit in December of 2018, and currently oversees municipal cases at the Daley Center. She previously worked as an assistant state’s attorney for 13 years, ten of those years in Will County and three in Cook County. Denmark ran unsuccessfully for a 15th subcircuit vacancy in 2014.
fields.ratingNotes: The bar associations all praised Denmark’s litigation experience, legal ability and temperament. The ISBA praised her for her “professionalism, preparation and fairness.”

fields.name: DANIEL O. TIERNAN
fields.bio:
Daniel O. Tiernan was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court 14th subcircuit in February 2019 and oversaw traffic cases at the Daley Center until late last year, when he was elected by the Circuit Court to serve as an associate judge. That vote left the 14th subcircuit seat open until the election; Tiernan is guaranteed to either remain an associate judge or, if elected, return to the Circuit Court. 

He previously worked as an investigator for the Cook County Independent Inspector General. Tiernan also spent over a decade as an assistant state’s attorney before working as a private attorney in criminal defense.
fields.notable: Tiernan’s appointment [sparked outrage](https://chicago.suntimes.com/2019/6/18/18684208/hispanic-black-officials-judges-cook-subcircuit-jason-ervin-anne-burke "Hispanic officials pile on in flap over judicial picks by Illinois Supreme Court Justice Anne Burke") from activists and elected officials. They were upset that Tiernan, who is white, was appointed in a district that is largely Latinx.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA wrote that Tiernan is “well regarded for his legal knowledge, legal ability, experience and integrity.” The ISBA also praised his experience and diligence. The CCL cited his knowledge, temperament and willingness to mentor younger attorneys.

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK - 1ST SUBCIRCUIT - CRAWFORD VACANCY
6th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 6th subcircuit extends northwest from West Town through Hermosa and north to Ravenswood. It also includes Wicker Park, Bucktown, Logan Square, Avondale and part of Humboldt Park.

fields.name: Reversing conviction, Ill. Appeals Court warns police deception violates trust
JESSE G REYES
fields.bio: Reyes first became a judge in 1997, when he won election by the Cook County Circuit judges as an associate judge. Before that, Reyes served as an attorney for the City of Chicago and then for the Chicago Board of Education. After a decade as associate judge, Reyes won election to the Circuit Court in 2008, and then to his current position on the Illinois Appellate Court in 2012. At public forums, Reyes has told audiences that he is a public servant, emphasizing his community work beyond the bench.
fields.notable: Reyes is the first Latino man on the Illinois Appellate Court and, if successful, would become the first Latino man on the state Supreme Court.
fields.ratingNotes: The bar associations highlighted Reyes’s experience and diligence. The CBA praised his “passionate commitment to the law and our justice system.” The ISBA said attorneys describe him as “a hard worker who is prepared, strict and fair.” The CCL said he is prepared for oral arguments and his opinions are “well written and well-reasoned.”

fields.name: Past controversy
fields.description: Controversy in a candidate's past may be an indicator of poor judgment, ethical failings or poor knowledge of the law.

fields.name: PAMELA "PAM" STRATIGAKIS
fields.bio: Pam Stratigakis spent the majority of her career in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office, where she worked at various times in the felony trial division, the narcotics division, and the sexual assault and domestic violence division. She now practices in the area of medical malpractice in the Chicago office of Lewis, Brisbois, Birsgaard & Smith.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA and CCL praised Stratigakis’s legal knowledge and varied litigation experience. The CBA added that she “served on the Internet Sex Crimes Against Children Task Force and was engaged in groundbreaking litigation against people involved in Internet sex crimes.”

fields.name: SANDRA GISELA RAMOS
fields.bio: Sandra Ramos was elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 2010, and retained in 2016. That year, she ran unsuccessfully as one of two challengers who sought to unseat Timothy C. Evans as Circuit Court chief judge. She currently is assigned to the law division, handling civil cases. Before joining the bench, Ramos worked for eight years for the Cook County State’s Attorney, and then worked in private practice specializing in criminal defense.
fields.notable: If elected, she would be the first Latina Appellate Court judge in Illinois. Jesse Reyes was the first Latino elected to the Illinois Appellate Court bench in 2012.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA said Ramos is an “experienced trial judge” and is regarded for her knowledge, ability and diligence. The CCL called her a “capable trial judge” but raised concerns about her limited experience “presiding over complex legal matters.” The ISBA said she doesn’t yet have enough experience, despite finding her “even keeled and diligent.”

fields.name: IRA I. SILVERSTEIN
fields.bio: Ira Silverstein served as an Illinois senator from the 8th district for two decades before losing the 2018 primary to Ram Villivalam. He served on a number of committees including the judiciary committee and executive committee throughout much of his time in office. He’s currently a private attorney with his own firm, focused on small business matters, elder law and estate planning.
fields.notable:
Victims’ rights advocate Denise Rotheimer accused Silverstein of sexual harassment at the end of 2017, leading to an investigation by then-Illinois Legislative Inspector General Julie Porter. The investigation concluded that Silverstein did not sexually harass Rotheimer while they worked together on legislative issues, but it did find that Silverstein’s behavior was “unbecoming of a legislator." Rotheimer has been critical of the investigation, claiming that the system is “rigged” against accusers and in favor of legislators.  Silverstein is married to Alderman Debra Silverstein of the 50th ward.
In an interview with *Injustice Watch*, Silverstein emphasized that he was cleared by the Inspector General. "I think that those findings are those findings, there was no evidence of sexual harassment," he said.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA, CCL and ISBA all expressed concerns about the depth and breadth of Silverstein’s legal experience as well as the sexual harassment allegations mentioned above.

fields.name: Dear Candidate: Are you a Communist?
Democratic primary for COOK - 6TH SUBCIRCUIT - NEGA VACANCY
MICHAEL HARRY MINTON
fields.bio: Michael Minton has specialized in divorce law throughout his long legal career. He gained [media attention](https://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/whats-a-wife-worth/Content?oid=871934) through a legal case and subsequent book in which he argued that homemaking should have higher value in divorce proceedings. Minton also ran in the 2002 Illinois State Senate race for the 27th District, which he lost in the general election.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL credited Minton for his legal knowledge and ability and his experience in domestic relations, and noted his good temperament. But the CBA and ISBA both raised concerns about his “diligence,” and the ISBA also questioned the depth and breadth of his trial experience.

fields.name: KEELY PATRICIA HILLISON
fields.bio: Keely Hillison has been an attorney for 30 years, first at Parrillo Weiss LLC, a Chicago law firm, where she was a partner, and now for her own firm. At Parrillo Weiss, Hillison supervised the firm’s insurance law and appellate practices. Since 2000, she has also served as an arbitrator in the Circuit Court of Cook County. Hillison ran unsuccessfully for a circuit court seat in 2018.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA rated Hillison qualified due to her legal experience, knowledge, calm demeanor, and diligence. The CCL also rated Hillison qualified, but noted that early in her career her firm was “accused of filing frivolous claims.” The ISBA expressed concerns over the extent of her experience, saying, “much of her practice consists of high-volume, simpler cases.”

fields.name: SCOTT EDWARD LIPINSKI
fields.bio: Scott Edward Lipinski has been a Cook County assistant public defender since shortly after being admitted to the bar in 2002. Lipinski has defended clients in jury and non jury trials at the Bridgeview courthouse. He has previously run unsuccessfully for multiple judicial positions, most recently in 2016.
fields.notable: Lipinski has received poor bar ratings after other lawyers accused him of sometimes losing his temper in court proceedings. In a 2016 *Injustice Watch* article, he strongly [denied](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2016/16-judge-candidates-fail-to-win-bar-support-but-will-voters-care/ "16 judge candidates fail to win bar support, but will voters care?") these accusations and said, “I’ve always been professional to any State’s Attorney or any judge.”
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA wrote that Lipinski “has criminal practice experience” but there were “concerns about his diligence and temperament.” The CCL said there were “several reports that Mr. Lipinski can be abrasive and lack courtesy.” The ISBA noted that he received “mixed comments regarding temperament” but praised his trial experience and legal knowledge.

fields.name: CELESTIA L. MAYS
fields.bio:
