Celestia Mays was appointed to a vacancy on the Cook County Circuit Court at the end of 2018 and began hearing cases in the Municipal Division in January 2019.  She served in this position until late last year, when she was elected by the Circuit Court judges to serve as an associate judge. That vote left the Circuit Court seat open until the election; Mays is guaranteed to either remain an associate judge or, if elected, return to the Circuit Court. 

Prior to her appointment, she focused on family and estate law as an attorney in private practice. Mays also previously served as the president of the Cook County Bar Association. She was a finalist for an associate judgeship in 2018, but she was not selected.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA said Mays “is hardworking and receives high marks for her fine temperament and people skills.” The CCL noted she is an “excellent practitioner with great integrity” who is “exceptionally active in community activities.” The ISBA commended Mays for her professionalism, diligence and temperament.

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK CIRCUIT- LARSEN VACANCY
Democratic primary for COOK - 10TH SUBCIRCUIT - O'BRIEN VACANCY
PAMELA REAVES-HARRIS
fields.currentJob: Special assistant for legal affairs at the Cook County Bureau of Economic Development
fields.bio: Pamela Reaves-Harris works for the Cook County Bureau of Economic Development as a special assistant for legal affairs. She served as a state representative for the 10th District in the Illinois General Assembly from 2015 to 2017. Prior to her time as a legislator, she worked as a private attorney and as an administrative law judge.
fields.notable: This seat on the 7th subcircuit is being temporarily filled by Cook County Sheriff’s policy director Cara Smith, who was appointed to the seat by the Supreme Court. Smith decided not to run for the seat after Reaves-Harris, among others, labeled Smith’s appointment a snub, because Smith is white and the 7th subcircuit is “a majority-minority district,” [according](https://chicago.suntimes.com/columnists/2019/7/26/8932096/pamela-reaves-harris-cook-county-circuit-court-anne-burke-west-side-chicago-laura-washington) to the Chicago Sun-Times. Reaves-Harris praised Smith’s decision not to run, saying that “this seat was created with the intent to give African Americans in that community representation in the judicial system.”
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL and ISBA highlighted her community service and temperament but noted some concerns about her lack of litigation experience. The CBA praised her legal knowledge and “fine demeanor.”

fields.name: CCL Highly Qualified
fields.description: The candidate has demonstrated excellence in the abilities required of a judge on the relevant court in all areas considered (e.g. fairness, competence, conduct, independence, integrity/character).

fields.name: JACQUELINE MARIE GRIFFIN
fields.bio: Jacqueline Griffin has been a Cook County assistant state’s attorney since she became a lawyer in 2005. For the past two years, Jacqueline has been a trial specialist in the sexual assault and domestic violence unit of the felony trial division.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Griffin’s “extensive criminal and civil trial experience.” The ISBA said attorneys reported Griffin is “diligent, punctual, respectful, and has good character and integrity.” The CCL complemented her experience in more complex matters.

fields.name: EILEEN MARIE O'CONNOR
fields.bio: Eileen Marie O'Connor has been an attorney in private practice, with a focus on personal injury, since she was admitted to the bar in 2006. In 2010, she joined her family’s law firm, the O’Connor Law firm, where she currently practices.
fields.notable: O’Connor has represented clients in several civil rights cases, including the family of Tyler Lumar, a young man who died in 2018 from injuries suffered in a suicide attempt while in Chicago police custody. Policle officers had arrested him in a mixup over a warrant issued by Lee County authorities over a $25 parking ticket that he had in fact paid.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL noted O’Connor’s experience in “complex legal matters,” her work ethic, and her pro bono work, and the CBA praised her legal knowledge and demeanor. The ISBA wrote, “Attorneys consider her professional, level-headed and prepared.”

fields.name: KELLY MARIE McCARTHY
fields.currentJob: Chief of legal resources division of the Cook County Public Defender’s Office
fields.bio: Kelly McCarthy has spent nearly all of her legal career in the Cook County Public Defender’s Office and currently heads the division specializing in appeals and other post-conviction matters. She has worked in several different areas during her time there, including the civil division, the felony trial division and the homicide task force.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA praised McCarthy’s organizational skills and temperament, the ISBA complemented her complex litigation experience, and the CCL said she is “knowledgeable and hard-working.”

fields.name: CHELSEY R. ROBINSON
fields.bio: Chelsey Robinson has worked as a private attorney for her law firm Owens & Robinson since she was admitted to the bar in 1996. Her firm specializes in cases related to bankruptcy, domestic relations, criminal defense, personal injury and worker's compensation. She previously ran unsuccessfully the 2016 Democratic primary for a 2nd subcircuit Cook County Circuit Court vacancy.
fields.notable: Robinson has [defended](https://www.chicagoreader.com/Bleader/archives/2013/08/26/how-stop-and-frisk-works-in-chicago "Chicago Reader") low-income clients who police allegedly subjected to controversial “stop-and-frisk” searches. Her law firm’s website says that the firm provides legal consultation to “The Judge Mathis Show.”
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA wrote that Robinson “has a wide range of practice experience and is well regarded for her knowledge of the law and diligence.” However, the ISBA expressed concerns about her “limited jury and bench trial activities and limited experience with complex matters.” CCL said she has “litigation experience in a variety of matters in both state and federal courts.”

fields.name: RUSSELL W. HARTIGAN
fields.bio: Russell Hartigan served as a  judge from 2010, when he was appointed to a Cook County Circuit Court vacancy,  to 2017. He won election to the seat in 2012, but stepped down in 2017 citing family health issues. During his tenure as a judge, Hartigan presided over civil cases in the Daley Center. Prior to his appointment to the bench, Hartigan worked in private practice for over 30 years, specializing in civil litigation including casualty and municipal defense, workers compensation and personal injury. He also served in several elected and appointed government roles in the suburbs of Berwyn, Lyons, and Western Springs. Since stepping down from the bench, he served for a year as the president of the Illinois State Bar Association.
fields.ratingNotes: Ratings for Hartigan were very positive. The CCL considered Hartigan “a well-respected jurist who was praised for his courtroom demeanor and management skills.” The CBA and ISBA gave Hartigan their highest rating. The ISBA wrote, “Attorneys have a high regard for his legal knowledge, preparedness and his approachable demeanor.”

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK CIRCUIT- FUNDERBURK VACANCY
Democratic primary for COOK - 14TH SUBCIRCUIT- BERTUCCI VACANCY
LAURA AYALA-GONZALEZ
fields.bio: Laura Ayala-Gonzalez currently works as an superving assistant state's attorney in the felony trial unit of the Cook County State’s Attorney's office. She has spent her entire 16-year legal career in the office, where she has served in the juvenile justice bureau, the gangs and complex homicide unit, and as a deputy supervisor in the felony review unit.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Ayala-Gonzalez is “well regarded by her colleagues” including judges and defense lawyers. The CCL stated that she “has substantial trial experience in complex matters.” The ISBA mentioned that attorneys gave her “high marks for her character and integrity.”

fields.name: CARMINE TROMBETTA
fields.bio: Carmine Trombetta is a sole practitioner in his Schaumberg law firm, where he has practiced since 1984. He represents clients in civil and criminal cases, including felonies, real estate issues, personal injury, and a number of other legal areas. Trombetta ran unsuccessfully in the 2018 Democratic primary for the 12th subcircuit.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA and CCL cited his litigation and jury experience and the ISBA said, “Attorneys, including adversaries, report that he is prepared, hard working and has a good understanding of legal issues.” Trombetta did not participate in the CBA’s evaluation process.

fields.name: CRISTIN KEELY McDONALD DUFFY
fields.bio: Cristin McDonald Duffy is deputy supervisor of the real estate tax division at the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office. She previously worked for 14 years in the office’s criminal division. Duffy has practiced law for 23 years.
fields.notable: In 2014, Duffy won a civil verdict against the Chicago Bears that required the sports team to pay Cook County millions of dollars in unpaid amusement taxes.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Duffy’s knowledge of the law and the fact that she “is also responsible for the State’s Attorney’s training and mentoring program in the Civil Division.” The ISBA said, “Attorneys report she is always very well prepared on both the facts and the law and was praised for her legal knowledge and ability.” The CCL praised her litigation skills.

fields.name: CCL Not Qualified
fields.description: The candidate has not demonstrated the abilities required of a judge on the relevant court in the areas considered (e.g. fairness, competence, conduct, independence, integrity/character).

fields.name: 1st Subcircuit
fields.description: The 1st subcircuit includes parts of the south and southeast sides of Chicago, including Chatham, South Chicago, East Side and Hegewisch, as well as the south suburbs of Burnham and Calumet City.

fields.name: Lawyer appointed as Cook County judge despite losing election, past judicial scoldings
ANNE SHAW
fields.bio: Anne Shaw has worked in private practice for the majority of her career. She focuses on civil cases related to human rights, commercial law and personal injury, and she founded a pro-bono legal clinic in Chinatown that generally serves immigrants. Shaw also holds a real estate license. She previously ran unsuccessfully for the Illinois General Assembly in 2018 and for alderman in 2015.
fields.notable: As previously [reported](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2020/judge-candidate-anne-shaw-had-real-estate-license-reprimanded-for-deceptive-practices/ "Judge candidate Anne Shaw had real estate license reprimanded for deceptive practices") by *Injustice Watch*, Shaw was given a reprimand on her real estate license in 2016 for “not properly supervising employees of Shaw Real Estate Group.” Multiple lawsuits accused the organization of preying on people with poor credit by demanding non-refundable fees for finding apartments. The Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation accused the Shaw Real Estate Group of deceptive business practices and unprofessional conduct, leading to a suspension of the organization’s license and an $18,000 fine. Shaw claims that the investigation and lawsuits were a “coordinated effort” to delegitimize her from her 2015 electoral opponent, Alderman Proco “Joe” Moreno.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA cited concerns about Shaw’s “diligence, punctuality and temperament,” and the ISBA wrote that “concerns were raised about her lack of jury trial, complex and recent litigation, as well as her organizational skills.” The CCL praised her legal ability and litigation experience but expressed concerns about the ethical issues mentioned above.

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK CIRCUIT- ROTI VACANCY
SUZANNE THERESE McENEELY
fields.bio: Suzanne McEneely has spent her career as public defender, having joined the office soon after becoming authorized to practice law in 2002. She has worked in a variety of roles within the Public Defender’s office, including the abuse and neglect division, the domestic violence division, and now the criminal division. She currently works at the Skokie Courthouse.
fields.notable: McEneely has filed for a notice of self-funding for her campaign. Her family has donated over $150,000 for the purposes of her election.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted McEneely’s “extensive trial experience.” The ISBA mentioned her “legal knowledge, diligence, ability to handle complex matters, sensitivity to diversity, and her temperament.”

fields.name: BASILEIOS "BILL" FOUTRIS
fields.bio: Basileios "Bill" Foutris is in private practice specializing in civil rights cases, and has represented several alleged victims of police misconduct. Before he opened his own firm in 2005, Foutris worked for three years as an associate at a lawfirm that defended police officers in civil cases.
fields.notable: Foutris represented the family of Quintonio LeGrier, 19, in a wrongful death lawsuit against the City of Chicago and police officer Robert Rialmo, following a well-publicized incident in which Rialmo fired shots that killed LeGrier and his neighbor, Bettie Jones, when he found LeGrier in emotional distress and swinging an aluminum bat. The jury awarded LeGrier’s estate more than $1 million in damages, a verdict reversed by the judge based on the jury’s finding that Rialmo had reasonably feared for his life.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA, CCL and ISBA all praised Foutris’s trial experience with high profile cases and his knowledge of the law. However, the CBA and ISBA reported some concerns about his temperament. The ISBA wrote, “A few attorneys interviewed felt that at time he took advantage of less-experienced colleagues” in resolving disputes and could be difficult to work with, but noted that “some attributed any such issues to his passion for his clients.”

fields.name: GERARDO TRISTAN, JR.
fields.bio: Gerardo Tristan Jr. was appointed to a Cook County Circuit Court 14th subcircuit seat in November 2018 and currently oversees traffic cases at the Daley Center. Prior to his appointment, he worked as an assistant state’s attorney for 15 years. Tristan had worked briefly upon graduating law school in private practice and for the Chicago Board of Education.
fields.ratingNotes: All three bar associations noted Tristan’s extensive trial experience and knowledge of the law. The ISBA said attorneys “specifically noted his proficiency in the technological aspects of courtroom litigation.” The CCL said respondents “praised his fairness.”

fields.name: KRISTA D. BUTLER
fields.currentJob: Public service administrator, Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services
fields.bio: Krista Butler has been a licensed attorney since 1993 and  is currently employed by the Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services. She previously worked as a public service administrator for the Illinois Guardianship and Advocacy Commission. Her legal focuses include guardianship and juvenile justice matters.
fields.ratingNotes: Butler was rated not recommended by the bar associations because she did not participate in the evaluation process.

fields.name: Cook County judicial candidate, colleague misled jury into wrongful conviction
ERIN HAGGERTY ANTONIETTI
fields.bio: Erin Antonietti worked as an assistant state’s attorney for over two decades before her June 2019 appointment to a Cook County Circuit Court vacancy. She currently hears traffic cases in the First Municipal Division. As state’s attorney, Antonietti prosecuted a wide range of cases, including violent felonies, domestic violence cases and traffic violations. Antonietti has also been an adjunct professor in the criminal justice program at Prairie State College.
fields.notable: Antonietti has loaned over $100,000 to her own campaign committee.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted that Antonietti is “well regarded by her fellow judges and by the lawyers who appear in her court.” The CCL highlighted her litigation experience and wrote that, since taking the bench, she has demonstrated “good legal ability, temperament, and the ability to manage high volume courtrooms.”

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK CIRCUIT- SHEEHAN, C. VACANCY
Democratic party pick
fields.description: The Cook County Democratic Party's endorsement is one of the most sought-after and influential factors in running for a countywide judicial seat. Endorsed candidates must have a positive Chicago Bar Association rating, are usually politically connected, and pledge $40,000 to the party's election coffers. In return, they receive the support of "the machine" in the form of foot solders, mailers and local officials able to rally large swaths of voters.

fields.name: LYNN WEAVER BOYLE
fields.bio: Lynn Weaver Boyle was appointed to the Cook County Circuit Court in December 2018. Prior to her appointment, Weaver Boyle worked at the Chicago office of Grotefeld Hoffman LLP, where she represented clients in commercial litigation. She began her legal career in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office, where she worked for almost a decade as an assistant state’s attorney in the criminal division. She currently hears municipal civil cases and traffic matters at the Daley Center.
fields.notable: Boyle’s election committee has raised over $250,000, most of which comes from her family.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA referenced Weaver Boyle’s extensive trial experience both in private practice and as an assistant state’s attorney, including her two years in the gang unit. The CCL called her a “respected practitioner with a good temperament.”

fields.name: ARACELI REYES DE LA CRUZ
fields.currentJob: General counsel, Acero Charter School Network
fields.bio: Araceli De La Cruz is general counsel for the Acero Charter School Network. Prior to that, she worked for the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation as the chief of general prosecutions and for the Chicago Transit Authority as a chief compliance officer and deputy chief of staff. De La Cruz started her career as a Cook County assistant state’s attorney. Over the course of a decade at the State’s Attorney’s office, she served in six different divisions, including the juvenile justice bureau, the sex crimes division, and the felony review division.
fields.notable: De La Cruz is the Democratic Party’s slated candidate for this race and her campaign is mostly self-funded. She loaned more than $70,000 to her campaign and has donated $30,000 to the Cook County Democractic Party.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA touted De La Cruz's managerial skills and said she was “hardworking.” The CCL noted her adeptness at “learning new law” and reputation for being “respectful” and a “zealous advocate” for her clients. The ISBA, however, cited concerns over “her overall legal experience and her minimal jury and complex trial experience.”

fields.name: NATHANIEL ROOSEVELT HOWSE
fields.bio: Nathaniel R. Howse Jr., was first elected to the Cook County Circuit Court in 1998, and retained in 2004. He received a temporary appointment to the Illinois Appellate Court in 2009, and won election to the seat in 2012. Before being elected to the bench, Howse was an attorney in private practice; his work included fighting to keep candidates of the Harold Washington Party, who ran against the Democratic party slated candidates, on the ballot. Howse was also, for a time, law partners with P. Scott Neville Jr., whom he is now running to unseat. Howse’s family migrated to Chicago from Tennessee, and he speaks of the impact of his childhood in a segregated community. He has also noted his efforts to eliminate any backlog of cases.
fields.notable: While Neville won the Democratic party endorsement for the seat, Howse enjoys the support of, among others, U.S. Congresswoman Jan Schakowsky and Illinois Secretary of State Jesse White.
fields.ratingNotes: Howse was praised by all three bar associations for his experience and legal reasoning. The CBA said he is “well regarded for his knowledge of the law and diligence in issuing opinions in a timely manner.” The ISBA said he is “polite to all, diligent and punctual.” The CCL highlighted his “excellent legal ability” and said he “is reported to demonstrate a good grasp of complex issues.”

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK - 10TH SUBCIRCUIT - McGING VACANCY
13th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 13th subcircuit covers the northwest suburbs of Palatine, Schaumburg, Hoffman Estates, South Barrington, and Streamwood.

fields.name: MABLE TAYLOR
fields.bio: Mable Taylor is a private attorney who has worked on both civil and criminal cases throughout her career. She has previously taught classes at several law schools and served as an arbitrator for Cook County. Taylor is running for a judicial seat for the fourth time in the last ten years.
fields.notable: Taylor worked on behalf of the failed effort by Cook County Clerk of Court Dorothy Brown to run for mayor of Chicago last year even while her office was under federal investigation. Taylor represented Brown in a petition challenge brought by Cook County Board President Toni Preckwinkle that caused Brown to be kicked off the ballot over the validity of her signatures.
fields.ratingNotes: Taylor was rated not recommended by the bar associations because she did not participate in the evaluation process.

fields.name: AILEEN BHANDARI
fields.bio: Aileen Bhandari has been a Cook County assistant state’s attorney for the past 16 years. She currently serves in the felony trial division, where she has prosecuted a wide range of felony cases including violent and white-collar crimes. According to her campaign site, Bhandari has held leadership roles in several legal organizations, including the South Asian Bar Association and the Filipino Lawyers Association of Chicago.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA touted Bhandari’s extensive trial experience, and the CCL said she “is described as having a commitment to understanding the needs of different communities and of crime victims from different backgrounds.” The ISBA said, “She is punctual, prepared, follows court rules, and presents evidence honestly and straightforwardly.”

fields.name: MAUREEN PATRICIA O'LEARY
fields.currentJob: Vice president of claims and litigation for Aperion Care, Inc.
fields.bio: Maureen Patricia O’Leary worked as a nurse before earning her law degree at John Marshall Law School. She has worked since 2002 as a licensed attorney. Early in her legal career, she spent a brief four months in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office. Since then, O’Leary has focused her career on medical and nursing home litigation, currently working as a vice president of claims and litigation at Aperion Care, Inc., a chain of assisted living facilities. O’Leary is the only candidate for the seat without judicial experience.
fields.notable: O’Leary has reported no outside donations or expenditures and, until late January, did not have a campaign committee or website. Campaign consultants and experts [told *Injustice Watch*](https://www.injusticewatch.org/news/2020/sham-candidates-for-judge-an-election-secret-youre-not-supposed-to-know-about/ "Sham candidates: The election secret you're not supposed to know about") that O’Leary is likely a “sham candidate,” in the race not to win but to siphon votes in order to help another candidate. O’Leary did not respond to multiple requests for comment.
fields.ratingNotes: The bar associations cited O’Leary’s lack of experience to be an appellate judge. The ISBA said she “lacks litigation experience and has no experience appearing before the Appellate Court.” The CCL said it is “concerned” that O’Leary is running for the Appellate Court and that she “lacks both litigation experience in complex matters and demonstrated substantial published writing.”

fields.name: ELIZABETH ANNE WALSH
fields.bio: Elizabeth Walsh has worked as a trial attorney in private practice throughout her career. She focuses on civil law and has defended individuals and businesses facing lawsuits in civil court.
fields.ratingNotes: Both the CBA and CCL cited Walsh’s trial experience and legal knowledge. The ISBA said, “Attorneys respect her for her legal knowledge, preparation, temperament, and professionalism.”

fields.name: Judicial candidate resigns from political position that appeared to violate ethics rules
Democratic primary for COOK - 6TH SUBCIRCUIT - PANTLE VACANCY
New Cook County judicial candidate becomes fourth with past discipline
Democratic primary for COOK CIRCUIT- MASON VACANCY
KRISTEN MARIE LYONS
fields.bio: Kristen Lyons is a solo practitioner focusing on civil law, including family and personal injury law. She has also represented workers before the Illinois Workers’ Compensation Commission. According to her campaign’s Facebook [page](https://www.facebook.com/pg/lyons4judge/about/?ref=page_internal), Lyons began her legal career in 2004 with the Chicago Police Department, where she helped review policies, procedures and law materials used to instruct police recruits.
fields.ratingNotes: Lyons was rated not recommended by CCL and ISBA because she did not participate in their evaluation process. The CBA praised her “extensive litigation experience in both defense and plaintiff cases.”

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK - 9TH SUBCIRCUIT - AXELROOD VACANCY
JAMIE GUERRA DICKLER
fields.bio: Jamie Guerra Dickler has been an assistant state’s attorney for her entire 14-year legal career. She is currently a first chair in the felony trial division, prosecuting a variety of felony cases, including murder, narcotics, fraud and sexual assault. Previously, she has worked in the misdemeanor, felony review and grand jury units.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Dickler’s “extensive experience” and “excellent demeanor.” The CCL praised her community involvement and wrote, “All reports indicate that Ms. Dickler is an ethical prosecutor with good abilities.” The ISBA highlighted her “substantial criminal jury and bench trial experience, including handling complex cases.”

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK CIRCUIT- COGHLAN VACANCY
MICHAEL A. FORTI
fields.bio:
Michael A. Forti was appointed to the Circuit Court in 2018 and served as a judge in the domestic relations division until late last year, when he was elected by the Circuit Court to serve as an associate judge. That vote left the 8th subcircuit seat open until the election; Forti is guaranteed to either remain an associate judge or, if elected, return to the Circuit Court. 

This is his second appointment to the bench by the Illinois Supreme Court, after he lost in the Democratic Party primary in 2018. He also ran unsuccessfully in 2012. Before his bids for office, Forti worked for 17 years in the City of Chicago Law Department and was chief counsel for the Illinois Department of Transportation.
fields.notable: While at the Chicago Law Department, Forti handled several high-profile cases, including one in which city attorneys—after nearly a decade—[reversed their position](https://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/the-shocking-truth/Content?oid=892462) by no longer fighting defendant Andrew Wilson’s torture claims against notorious former Chicago Police Commander Jon Burge and others, while still arguing that some of the judgement in the case should not be paid by the city. Forti was also [lead counsel](http://primaries2012.elections.chicagotribune.com/editorial/michael-a-forti/index.html) for a case brought against the city of Chicago over its handgun ownership ban. The U.S. Supreme Court later [struck down the ban](https://www.cnn.com/2010/CRIME/06/28/us.scotus.handgun.ban/index.html). Forti is openly gay and an advocate for LGBTQ rights.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Forti’s varied legal experience and “fine demeanor.” The CCL wrote, “As a judge, he continues to receive very positive marks,” including for his handling of self-represented litigants in a manner that is “respectful and informative without going beyond the role of judge.”

fields.name: MAIRE AILEEN DEMPSEY
fields.currentJob: Partner at Hughes Socol Piers Resnick & Dym
fields.bio: Maire Aileen Dempsey has been a licensed attorney since 2002 and has worked at various law firms throughout her career. For the past 14 years, Dempsey has practiced medical malpractice defense. She is currently a partner at Hughes Socol Piers Resnick & Dym, Ltd. in Chicago.
fields.ratingNotes: All three bar associations noted Demsey’s experience handling complex litigation. The CBA said she is “well regarded for her integrity, diligence, knowledge of the law, and excellent demeanor.” The ISBA said she is “known to be prepared and professional” and the CCL praised her temperament and legal ability.

fields.name: Appointed judge
fields.description: Appointed judges are those who have been appointed by the state Supreme Court to temporarily fill a vacancy. Having experience as a judge is a positive qualification, and the vetting that accompanies the nomination process may screen out unqualified candidates. However, according to Professor Tonja Jacobi of Northwestern University's Pritzker School of Law, "In Chicago, it probably is an indication that you've rubbed a lot of shoulders with a lot of political types."

fields.name: NICHOLE C. PATTON
fields.bio: Nichole Patton was appointed to a Cook County Circuit Court vacancy in June 2018 and currently oversees cases in the county division at the Daley Center. She had two separate stints in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office, most recently in the mental health unit, where she sought civil commitment orders for individuals at mental health hospitals in Cook County. She also spent several years in private practice doing both civil and criminal defense, as well as transactional law and medical malpractice defense. This is her fourth run for the bench after losing elections in 2010 and 2012 and pulling out of a 2014 Appellate Court primary race.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA praised Patton for her “extensive knowledge and experience in mental health law,” her temperament, and her treatment of unrepresented parties in her court. The ISBA said she is “well-prepared and is fair with a good temperament.” CCL reported that she is “a zealous advocate who is trustworthy and respectful both to clients and opposing counsel.”

fields.name: JENNIFER PATRICIA CALLAHAN
fields.bio: Jennifer Callahan practices in the areas of criminal defense and transactional work as an attorney in private practice. After graduating from law school, she worked as an assistant Cook County state’s attorney, serving in the first municipal division, the narcotics prosecutions bureau, and the alternative prosecutions unit. Callahan has also worked as an administrative law judge and as retained counsel for an in-house insurance defense firm defending employment claims.
fields.notable: Callahan has filed a notice of self-funding and has loaned her campaign $100,000.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted her “knowledge of the law and legal ability,” and the CCL praised her litigation skills. The ISBA said Callahan is “prepared, punctual, and knowledgeable with high integrity.”

fields.name: 12th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 12th subcircuit includes the northern suburbs of Winnetka, Glencoe, Northbrook and Wheeling and the northwest suburbs of Des Plaines, Mt. Prospect and Arlington Heights.

fields.name: 14th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 14th subcircuit covers much of the Southwest Side of Chicago, including Bridgeport, Back of the Yards, Little Village, Brighton Park, and Gage Park, and the suburb of Cicero. It is home to the Leighton Criminal Court House and the Cook County Jail at 26th and California.

fields.name: HOWARD J. WISE
fields.bio: Howard J. Wise began his legal career in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office, where he worked for three years, including in the felony review unit. In 2001, he left the State’s Attorney’s office and became a private defense attorney. He started his own law firm in 2006, where he specializes in criminal defense.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA said Wise is “hardworking and well regarded” for his knowledge and legal ability. The ISBA noted that he’s considered to be “smart and informed, professional and diligent” and cited his bench trial experience. The CCL praised Wise’s experience and said he is a “solid practitioner with good legal ability and temperament.”

fields.name: Former state's attorney
fields.description: History as a state's attorney is an important qualification in terms of experience, but there is some [evidence](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1745-9125.1988.tb00858.x) that former prosecutors may be less sympathetic to civil rights claimants and economic "underdogs" (consumers, tenants, etc.) and tend to side with the government — particularly in the case of criminal defendants.

fields.name: DAVID A. BONOMA
fields.currentJob: Partner at Linebarger Goggan Blair & Sampson
fields.bio: David A. Bonoma is a partner in the Chicago office of Linebarger Goggan Blair & Sampson, one of the country’s biggest government debt collectors. From 1997 to 2003, Bonoma served as chief of staff to Cook County State’s Attorney Dick Devine. In 2005, Bonoma and Victor Reyes, the longtime Richard M. Daley aide and Hispanic Democratic Organization founder, founded Reyes & Bonoma Ltd., a lobbying and legal firm. Bonoma was appointed to the Illinois Employment Security Board of Review in 2010 by then-Governor Pat Quinn. He also had a brief stint as an external affairs director for ComEd in 2012 and 2013.
fields.notable:
In addition to being Victor Reyes’s partner in their lobbying firm, Bonoma worked as a registered lobbyist with Reyes’s Roosevelt Group from 2005 to 2007. During his time as a lobbyist, Bonoma advocated on behalf of Chicago Aviation Partners, a firm with close [ties](https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-2011-06-11-ct-met-ohare-concessions-20110611-story.html) to Daley, and H.W. Lochner, a construction engineering firm that has received large contracts from the City of Chicago. Bonoma and his wife have contributed $14,000 to political campaigns since 2005, and his firms contributed more than $52,000 in that time.

In an email to *Injustice Watch*, Bonoma emphasized that it has been almost a decade since he worked with Mr. Reyes. “I can’t remember the last time I saw him or spoke with him,” he wrote.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA and CCL both praised Bonoma’s wide-ranging legal experience and his strong work ethic, but they also expressed concerns about his limited trial experience. The ISBA raised concerns over his “lack of jury and bench trial experience.”

fields.name: DANIEL L. COLLINS
fields.bio: Daniel Collins works in private practice, specializing in worker compensation and other business and employment litigation. He started his career as an assistant state’s attorney in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office. Collins previously ran in the 2018 Democratic primary for the Cook County Circuit Court 4th subcircuit under the name Danny Collins. He was elected in 2019 to the Board of Commissioners of the Park District of La Grange.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA praised Collins’s “depth and breadth” of experience, and the ISBA wrote he is “level-headed.” Both the ISBA and the CCL commended his “excellent research and writing skills.”

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK - 7TH SUBCIRCUIT - JACKSON VACANCY
8th Subcircuit
fields.description: The 8th subcircuit extends north along the lakefront from Chinatown to Edgewater, and includes the South Loop, the Loop, Near North Side, Lincoln Park, Lakeview and Uptown.

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK - 15TH SUBCIRCUIT - GRIFFIN VACANCY
THOMAS G. O'BRIEN
fields.bio: Thomas G. O’Brien began his legal career as an assistant attorney general for Illinois before entering private practice in 2003. He spent several years as an environmental scientist before he began law school, working on projects with the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. O’Brien previously ran unsuccessfully for a Cook County Circuit Court 3rd subcircuit seat in the 2010 Democratic primary.
fields.ratingNotes: O’Brien was rated not recommended by the bar associations because he did not participate in the evaluation process.

fields.name: MARY CATHERINE MARUBIO
fields.bio: Mary Catherine Marubio has been an associate judge in the Cook County Circuit Court since 2016. She is currently assigned to the pretrial division and was previously assigned to the domestic relations division. Prior to her election to the bench, she worked at the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation as an administrative law judge and as the chief of the prosecutions bureau. Marubio has also worked in criminal defense as a private attorney.
fields.notable: Marubio is active in the LGBTQ community and in 2019 received the Community Leadership Award from the Illinois State Bar Association’s Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity Committee. She has also served on the board of the ACLU of Illinois.
fields.ratingNotes: The ISBA reported that Marubio “has a keen intellect, is a hard worker and has a good temperament” and the CBA said she is “dedicated to her assignments.” The CCL said that, as a lawyer, Marubio was a “smart, solid practitioner with a variety of litigation experiences.”

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK - 3RD SUBCIRCUIT - FILAN VACANCY
GARY WILLIAM SEYRING
fields.bio: Gary Seyring has worked throughout his decades-long career in private practice on a wide range of civil matters, including business and family law. He has also done arbitration for the Cook County Arbitration Program. Seyring is running in the 13th subcircuit for the fourth time, after losing in the primaries in 2014 and 2016 and, after winning the Republican primary in 2018, losing in the general election.
fields.notable: In 2018, Seyring’s campaign Facebook page identified him as “the only true conservative Republican in the race for judge.”
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL said a “substantial percentage” of Seyring’s practice involves litigation and the ISBA said he is considered “a well-prepared litigator.” The CBA said Seyring is “actively involved in community service and highly regarded by the judges before whom he has appeared.”

fields.name: JAMES JOHN KNIBBS
fields.bio: James J. Knibbs is a private attorney who practices across a wide range of legal areas, including commercial litigation, civil rights defense and white-collar criminal defense. Knibbs serves of counsel to the law firm Foran Glennon Palandech Ponzi & Rudloff. From 1985 to 1989, he was an assistant Cook County state's attorney. He then spent more than a decade in private practice before returning to the State's Attorney's office from 2002 to 2008 in various roles that included supervisor of Public Corruption and Financial Crimes Unit.  He also taught trial advocacy at Loyola Law School from 2003 to 2009.
fields.notable: Knibbs has represented “over 60 Chicago police officers in federal lawsuits,” according to his campaign website. He also helped [prosecute](https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-2006-09-09-0609090050-story.html "Charges describe a reign of terror") a case against several CPD officers in 2006. Knibbs and former State’s Attorney Richard Devine worked together in private practice for several years after they left government, as partners at Meckler Bulger Tilson.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Knibbs’s “wide range of civil and criminal litigation experience,” and the CCL highlighted his legal ability and his reputation for being “diligent and punctual.”

fields.name: KERRIE MALONEY LAYTIN
fields.bio: Judge Kerrie Maloney Laytin presides over municipal cases in Chicago. She was appointed to fill a Cook County Circuit Court vacancy in late 2018.  Prior to her appointment, she was a longtime attorney for the City of Chicago, working in the Law Department appeals division. She has also represented the city in several high profile cases, including an Illinois Supreme Court case about the constitutionality of Chicago’s red light camera enforcement program. Earlier in her career, she worked briefly as a staff attorney for the Legal Assistance Foundation, and had a short stint as a civil trial attorney at the U.S. Department of Justice.
fields.ratingNotes: The CBA noted Laytin’s legal knowledge and deliberate demeanor. The ISBA called Laytin “professional” and “courteous.” The CCL also praised Laytin’s legal skills, but was concerned about her trial experience: “She has no notable trial experience but we believe that her appellate career has demonstrated the analytical thinking and management skills necessary to be a good Circuit Judge.”

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK - 2ND SUBCIRCUIT - A VACANCY
Democratic primary for COOK CIRCUIT- BELLOWS VACANCY
LORRAINE MARY MURPHY
fields.bio: Lorraine Murphy has spent much of her career at the Cook County State’s Attorney’s office, where she has prosecuted a variety of different types of cases in the felony trial division. Prior to her legal career, she worked in broadcast journalism. This is Murphy’s second run for the bench after an unsuccessful bid for a 10th subcircuit seat in 2018.
fields.ratingNotes: The CCL and CBA noted Murphy’s trial experience and courtroom skills. The ISBA wrote that she is respected as an “accomplished attorney with impressive legal knowledge.” Murphy is a CBA member and she served on their Judicial Evaluation Committee.

fields.name: Democratic primary for COOK - 8TH SUBCIRCUIT - FLEMING VACANCY
Democratic primary for COOK - 14TH SUBCIRCUIT- LACY VACANCY
